security_audit.summary: Documentation and reference skill for Mac AppleScript automation. Uses standard osascript command to execute AppleScript for legitimate macOS application control. All capabilities match stated purpose. User-initiated operations with confirmation requirements for destructive actions.

low_findings.title: File deletion operations
low_findings.description: The skill includes AppleScript patterns for deleting files via Finder (move to trash) and emptying trash. Quote from references/finder-applescript.md lines 98-106: "move targetFile to trash". While legitimate for file management, these operations could cause data loss if misused.

low_findings.title: System power commands
low_findings.description: The skill documents commands for sleep, restart, shutdown, and lock screen via System Events. Quote from references/system-applescript.md lines 258-281. These commands affect system state but require user confirmation and macOS permissions.

low_findings.title: Email deletion operations
low_findings.description: The skill includes patterns for deleting emails via Mail app. Quote from references/mail-applescript.md lines 163-173: "delete msg". This could result in permanent email deletion but requires Mail app permissions and user intent.

content.value_statement: Control macOS applications and system functions through natural language commands. Send emails, manage reminders, open websites, adjust volume, and more without leaving your AI assistant.
actual_capabilities: Send and manage emails through Mail app
Create and manage reminders with due dates
Create calendar events with times and locations
Control Safari tabs, URLs, and execute JavaScript
Manage files and folders via Finder operations
Adjust volume, display notifications, and control system settings
limitations: Requires macOS with accessibility and automation permissions granted
Only works with applications that support AppleScript
Cannot automate apps without proper macOS permissions configured

use_cases.title: Quick daily briefing
use_cases.description: Get your daily calendar events and unread emails in seconds without opening multiple apps.

use_cases.title: Create reminders from text
use_cases.description: Turn clipboard content or conversation text into reminders with due dates automatically.

use_cases.title: Browser and file control
use_cases.description: Open URLs, manage tabs, and organize files through simple voice or text commands.

prompt_templates.title: Send email
prompt_templates.prompt: Send an email to [recipient] with subject [subject] and body [message content].

prompt_templates.title: Create reminder
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a reminder called [task name] due [date/time] in my [list name] list.

prompt_templates.title: Add calendar event
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a calendar event for [event name] on [date] at [time] at [location].

prompt_templates.title: Morning briefing
prompt_templates.prompt: Give me a briefing of my calendar for today and list my unread emails from Mail.

output_examples.input: Create a reminder to call Mom tomorrow at 3pm

best_practices: Grant automation permissions in System Preferences before first use for each application
Confirm destructive operations like delete or empty trash before executing
anti_patterns: Running automation without checking application permissions first
Executing delete commands without user confirmation
Assuming all third-party applications support AppleScript

faq.question: Which macOS versions are supported?
faq.answer: Requires macOS with AppleScript support (10.4+). Most features work on modern macOS versions including Ventura, Sonoma, and Sequoia.

faq.question: What are the permission limits?
faq.answer: Each application requires explicit Automation permission in System Preferences > Privacy & Security. First runs trigger macOS permission dialogs.

faq.question: Can this integrate with other tools?
faq.answer: Yes, works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Can chain with other Bash commands and MCP tools for complex workflows.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: All operations run locally on your Mac via osascript. No data is sent externally. You control what information is accessed.

faq.question: Why did my script fail?
faq.answer: Common causes: app not running, incorrect app name, missing permissions, or syntax error. Check System Preferences permissions and ensure app is installed.

faq.question: How does this compare to Shortcuts?
faq.answer: AppleScript offers deeper control over application internals. Shortcuts provides visual workflow design. Use AppleScript for app-specific automation requiring precise control.
